pullRequest.title: MULE-18542: Timer threads leak on redeploy when using Oracle Driver.

nodes.bodyText: this test in inherently flaky.
Use a PollingProber
use a constant for the prefix of the Thread
static import
move this to a field so that the property is not read every time a it is used.
static import.
Are we sure this will be the only threads that are stopped in every kind of app? Isn't there a less intrusive way to shutdown the timer threads?
refactor this as a method.

use Boolean.getBoolean which verifies if there exists a system property, otherwise it assigns a default.
Use a constant for the string and rename this as jdb.resource.releaser.avoid.dispose.oracle.threads

You should only use getBoolean without the getProperty
getBoolean(AVOID_DISPOSE_ORACLE_THREADS_PROPERTY_NAME)
Return true if and only if the system property is true.
Add a comment to explain why this has to be done and that the timer cannot be cancelled by reflection (some users may use only the ojdbc jar)
HAManger-> HAManager
WARN
this should log not only the message, but the context in which it happened and the entire exception
this doesn't make sense. If this is a concern, then the two while loops should be nested and this one should be the master iteration
this doesn't look correct. By doing this, you're completely bypassing the lookup policies. Why is this needed? In which case would the driver not be loaded by the extension classloader?
this logger should be static
this looks incorrect. You need to check that the thread was started by the application being disposed, not by the classloader that loaded this class. Also, have you considered domains here?
same as before. Doesn't look like you're asserting the correct thing
don't do this. The runtime will use this by calling the release() method. Therefore, simply call the release method
no System.out in tests

this is testing nothing:

You're not testing the classloading navigation part. This doesn't give any indication on wether this actually works with the DB connector
You're starting a timer, but at no point you gave it the correct name
You're not considering the possibility of the thread not being found and the check() never taking place.
